PictureMultiSelect.Question: Which of the images show a representation of the brutal "middle passage" that enslaved Africans endured? Choose two images.
PictureMultiSelect.policy: Score points when all answers are correct.

TextMultpleChoice.Question: There were many ways for enslaved people to try and cope with the inhuman conditions of slavery. What plan is William considering at the key turning point in this narrative?
TextMultpleChoice.Answers: Armed revolt by enslaved people against slaveholders Flight to safety by enslaved people on the Underground Railroad Working together with the slaveholder to create better working conditions Utilizing inspiration from the stories of the enslaved Hebrews for hope

PictureMultpleChoice.Question: Which map would be most helpful to determine which colonies held the largest numbers of enslaved Africans?

TextMultiSelect.Question: Makiadi's name was changed to "William". In what other ways did enslaved Africans have their culture and traditions systematically destroyed?
TextMultiSelect.Answers: Enslaved people rarely interacted with other enslaved Africans Enslaved people were converted to Christianity Enslaved people were forced to use English to communicate Enslaved people were not allowed to sing, dance, or create art Enslaved people were given only basic European style clothing
TextMultiSelect.policy: Score points when all answers are correct.

TextMultpleChoice.Question: Analyze the image of William. Which of the following conclusions are supported by the image?
TextMultpleChoice.Answers: Some enslaved people were skilled and worked with tools Enslaved people lived in houses made from strong materials such as bricks Enslaved people were given adequate clothing and supplies to be comfortable William cooperated with the slave holder and worked as an overseer William had scars from abusive treatment
